text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with ricotta pie that's right while
this rustic Italian dessert may not be
as sweet or rich or ginormous as the
kind of cheesecake that might be
produced in a factory it's delicious in
its own right and incredibly easy to
make unless of course you decide to do a
cannoli inspired version and make your
own special crust it's kind of a hybrid
between a cookie and a pie crust which
is what I did but even with that it was
still pretty simple and here's how it
went down so the first thing I did was
make my crust and I'm going to do that
right my food processor and it's gonna
start with some flour just all-purpose
flour we're also going to add a little
bit of salt a touch of sugar just white
sugar a little bit of baking powder
no not baking soda that's different
baking powder I'm also going to crack in
an egg and because as I mentioned I am
doing a cannoli inspired pie I'm going
to add a little touch of cinnamon we're
also going to need some cold butter and
then before we move on to the always
popular pulsing on and off step I'm a
toss in a splash of Marsala wine and of
course wine is a very typical ingredient
in a cannoli show and even though the
texture is going to be totally different
we can still kind of go for those
flavors at that point we can go ahead
and pulse this out and off for about a
half a minute oh by the way if I wasn't
filming a video I would have totally
stopped and scraped down that egg and
cinnamon from the side but I was but
anyway we're gonna pull that on and off
mostly what we're trying to do here is
cut that butter into the dry ingredients
so we're gonna pulse it out and off
until it kind of looks like this alright
should be pretty coarse looking all
those little pieces are actually pieces
of butter and then the final step here
we're going to drip in just enough ice
water to make this come together into a
dough so we're gonna add a little ice
water and we're going to pulse it on and
off until it just comes together and
when that happens it's going to look
like this I know what you're thinking
shouldn't it come together in a dough
ball no that would be over mixed because
what we're going to do at this point is
dump that onto a floured work surface
and form this into a ball of dough with
our hands okay if you kept mixing it in
the food processor until this happened
it might get over mixed and your crust
could be a little tough for the new ones
so best to stop too soon and finish with
your hands and once that dough does come
together we're simply going to press it
into a disk and then we want to wrap
that in plastic and chill it very
thoroughly before we try to make the pie
it is critical that this dough is cold
before you work with it and did I wait
course not so I didn't wait but you
really should it is much easier to work
with so let your dough chill thoroughly
at which point you're going to dust it
with flour and roll it out to about an
eighth of an inch thick and by the way
on the blog post I'm going to give you
all your different options for crust
here and believe it or not you can even
skip this step but like I said we'll
cover that on the blog and once we have
that rolled out we're going to transfer
that into your standard glass 9-inch pie
dish and really the easiest and safest
way to do that would just be to roll
your dough over your rolling pin like
this just roll it back place your pie
dish down and just roll it back over so
easy and once that does been placed in
your pie dish we're going to take a
knife and go around the outside around
the outside around the outside trimming
off all the extra dough and you might be
thinking why didn't you just use less
ingredients for the pie crust because
one egg so because I was using one egg I
didn't want to use less dry ingredients
the proportions would have been off the
good news is you can reuse this dough so
you can wad that up and use it again
anyway we're going to trim that off and
then as usual I want to give a nice
little design around the edge of the
crust and of course I'm using the
technique my mother Pauline taught me
simply pushing one finger into two
fingers hey who said crimping ain't easy
crimping is totally easy and once that's
been done we're going to take a fork and
dock the dough which means just take the
fork and prick it all over this is going
to help it prevent from puff it up when
we blind-bake it which is the next step
so once that's been docked I'm going to
add a circle of parchment paper
on top of which we're going to add our
baking weights and if you don't have
these which you probably don't you can
simply use dried beans they work great
so we'll toss those in we'll spread
those around and then we're going to go
ahead and blind-bake as it's called this
pie in a 400 degree oven for 15 minutes
and after 15 minutes we're going to pull
it out let it cool for a few minutes
we're gonna carefully remove those
baking weights and then all we need to
do is let that sit continuing to cool
while we make our ricotta filling which
is ridiculously easy so in a mixing bowl
I'm gonna add the star of the show some
beautiful fresh ricotta cheese also
sometimes referred to as we got it's a
jersey thing and then in addition to our
beautiful cheese we're going to add some
eggs four whole eggs plus two yolks
we're also going to need some pure
vanilla extract and a healthy dose of it
as well as some freshly grated orange
and lemon zest and of course you can
just use one or the other or neither
it's up to you you're the one
responsible for making sure your ricotta
pie is super fly so you make the call
I'm going to use both and then last and
certainly least we need some sugar but
not that much I'm only using about a
third of a cup and at that point we can
take a whisk and mix this until it's
completely smooth and don't worry when
you first start mixing it's going to
look terrible
it'll look all separated and broken and
you'll think something went wrong and
you'll be cursing my name which by the
way is highly inappropriate but then all
of a sudden it will start coming
together and we'll look all gorgeous
like this and that is pretty much it for
the filling and at that point let's go
ahead and transfer that into our
prepared pie shell and if you want you
could bake it just like this but as I
mentioned earlier I wanted to do kind of
a cannoli inspired pie so I decided to
add some chopped candied orange zest and
chocolate and I could have just mixed
that right to the batter but I'm always
afraid of this stuff sinking to the
bottom plus by scattering it like this
first you can get a really great idea of
how much is going to be in each bite
so I scattered that over and then so it
mixes in without sinking I'm going to
take the tip of my knife and just kind
of poke that stuff down kind of stir it
in with the tip of the knife and I think
that allows for those ingredients
especially the chocolate to be more
suspended in the batter then like I said
just sink to the bottom
but whatever you could probably just mix
it in and then once I did that I decided
to scatter a few more over the top so it
would look nice after it baked which
basically ended up not being the case
but that's okay you got to take chances
in life but anyway threw out a few more
chips and at that point it's ready for
the oven so we're gonna place that into
the center of a 350 degree oven for 45
minutes or until it looks like this and
is just barely set and while it should
be perfect after 45 minutes really the
best way is to check with a thermometer
we want to shoot for about 160 internal
temp and if you get to and stop at that
temperature the texture of your pies
should be beautifully creamy and
luxurious and as it cools you kind of
see it sink down a little don't be
alarmed totally normal and at that point
our ricotta pie is ready to not eat you
really do want to chill this completely
before serving so I refrigerated mine
for a few hours before I sliced it and
then again keeping with a cannoli theme
I decided to garnish with a little bit
of chopped pistachio oops I think that
was a show let me take that off I'm not
trying to get sued again and besides the
pistachio I also decided to do a little
extra candied orange zest moistened with
a little bit of simple syrup kind of
scattered here and there
which I thought looked kind of nice but
anyway that's it ricotta pie so simple
so easy and a really delicious change of
pace from your more traditional
american-style cheesecakes so this is
definitely a lot lighter approach and as
I mentioned my strange hybrid crust is
optional I thought it was good but this
pie is also delicious with no crust or
graham cracker crust and no matter what
kind of crush you use is just one of
those simple dessert recipes everybody
should know okay so I really do hope you
give this a try head over to food wishes
calm for all the ingredient amounts and
more infos usual and as always enjoy
